abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Human Immunodeficiency
            Virus Infection / Acquired Immunode Ficiency Syndrome
            (HIV/AIDS) Prevention Project for Afghanistan were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was substantial; bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: preparation and
            effective implementation of an HIV/AIDS project in
            Afghanistan demonstrated that innovative programming is
            possible even in situations of extreme fragility and low
            counterpart capacity; the use of Non-Government Organization
            (NGO) contracting for service delivery, although challenged
            by delays in defining and implementing a selection process
            in a limited field of potential candidates, built on solid
            experience in this innovative approach and helped form the
            model for future projects; the efficiency of HIV prevention
            programs is greatly enhanced by the generation of
            epidemiological data to guide allocations to those
            populations and regions at greatest risk; the effectiveness
            of HIV prevention programs depends on technical strength of
            evidence-based interventions, adequate coverage of target
            populations with services and a permissive legal and policy
            framework; and the World Bank has been a global leader in
            providing services to vulnerable and marginalized
            populations in the HIV epidemic.

abstracts.cdata!:
The HIV/AIDS Prevention Project will
            contribute to Afghanistan's national development goals
            of maintaining HIV prevalence below 0.5 percent in the
            general population and below 5 percent among vulnerable
            groups at high risk of infection. The project's
            development objectives are to slow down the spread of HIV
            and build up the national capacity to respond to the
            epidemic. This will be accomplished by: (a) behavior change
            among vulnerable groups at high risk; and (b) improving
            knowledge of HIV prevention and reducing stigma related to
            HIV and AIDS in the general population. The project has four
            components: communications and advocacy activities will aim
            to increase knowledge of HIV prevention among opinion
            leaders and the general population, and reduce stigma and
            discrimination against vulnerable groups at high risk of HIV
            and AIDS; strengthening HIV surveillance through biological
            and behavioral surveys and knowledge attitudes and practice
            studies; targeted interventions for people engaged in high
            risk behaviors, including injecting drug use and unsafe sex;
            and program management, capacity building, monitoring and
            evaluation, and an Innovation Initiative to promote multi
            sector activities in support of project objectives.

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - HIV / AIDS Prevention Project
            : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the HIV /
            AIDS Prevention Project for Afghanistan is to slow down the
            spread of AIDS / HIV and build up the national capacity to
            respond to the epidemic. This environmental management plan
            evaluated potential adverse environmental impacts due to the
            treatment and disposal of infectious bio-medical waste, such
            as sharps (infected needles and syringes, IV sets, infected
            blood, HIV test kits used in VCT centers) related to the to
            the testing, transportation, treatment and prevention of HIV
            / AIDS, STI. As a result of this assessment the EA document
            list the following recommendations : human tissues, organs
            will be incinerated and buried deep into the ground;
            microbiology and biotechnology waste from laboratories will
            be incinerated, local autoclaving and microwave; waste
            sharps that may cause puncture and cuts (needles, scalpels,
            blades, glass, syringes, etc.) will be disinfected by using
            chemical treatment, autoclaving, microwaving and shredding;
            outdated, contaminated and discarded medicines and Cytotoxic
            drugs will disposed to secure landfills or incinerated; ash
            from incineration of any bio-medical waste will be disposed
            to the local municipal landfill; waste containers should
            contain freshly prepared disinfectant solution and be kept
            closed all the time; infected linen in hospitals should be
            carefully packed in plastic bags and disinfected before
            being sent for washing, all equipment used for bio-medical
            waste treatment should be periodically subject to
            maintenance checks to ensure its correct functioning;
            barrier protection (gowns, masks, caps, gloves, shoes
            covers, etc., should be used by workers to prevent contact
            with contaminated blood and body fluids; conduct a baseline
            assessment of training needs for health-care workers (HCW)
            participating in the implementation of the AIDS Control
            Program; and finally, a log of quantity of waste generated
            by type, name of waste handler, time of emptying waste
            container, time of cleaning waste container and pouring
            disinfectant should be maintained.
